CatDescriptText: Mrs. Eugene Woods, clerical worker of the Department of Public Assistance, 130 Mayflower Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 24, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that the increasing demand for father and mother to work, thus taking both parents out of the home for the better part of the day, affects their children as regards discipline, ambition, and social compatibility in general?" answer reads: "I think so, particularity for a small child.  Also, I might include those in age group from 6 to 15.  In those age groups, the children need the strictest discipline because these are the formative years, and they need the supervision of both parents and lots of it."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Mrs. Eugene Woods, wearing light colored hat, earrings, button down textured coat, and light colored gloves, holding handbag over right arm, standing with hands clasped together in front of stone building with store windows on either side, including one reading "Wholes... Only"
